p: Third, in addition to climate change, the potentially long-lasting (multidecadal) effects of land-use change in Syria is shown to affect the magnitude and timing of streamflow in the transboundary Yarmouk basin that supplies water to Jordan. Most notably, when accounting for the plausible recovery to pre-conflict status in the future, the decline in streamflow entering Jordan due to an increase in Syrian agricultural land use to pre-conflict levels is twice that attributable to climate change.
